I will pass on your story and thanks to the individual staff and teams you mentioned, they will be delighted to know they have made a difference, that's what we all come to work to do and it is really lovely to hear.  
I wish you all the very best for continued recovery and good health. Take care.  
Tracy

signature: Hendford Lodge Medical Centre, Yeovil
body:
Dear Patient, 

We sincerely apologise that you have had a negative experience when contacting the practice.

Our reception team were working to the practice protocol when you were offered an appointment with our clinical pharmacist, to discuss a high blood pressure. This is not because they deem it to be an unimportant issue, but because our clinical pharmacist leads on hypertension for the practice and is able to provide clinical advice and guidance, for an elevated blood pressure reading. 

We are sorry to hear that you missed your telephone appointment and encountered difficulties in reaching the practice to re-arrange this. If you would like to contact the practice, we would gladly re-arrange this for you. If you have any further concerns, please do not hesitate to contact us by emailing somicb.hendfordlodge-contact@nhs.net and mark this for the attention of the Practice Manager

Yours sincerely.
Hendford Lodge Medical Centre

signature: Werrington Health Centre
body: We are sorry that you have had difficulty with obtaining medication. At the time of changing your address, whoever informed us of the new address would have been told that you would be unable to remain on our list if you were moving to an area outside of our practice boundary - we would be unable to maintain safe  health care provision if we continued to provide treatment to all patients who do not reside within our catchment area - this policy has been in place for a number of years.  Patients are given approximately 40 days to register with their local service and are able to receive our healthcare within that time.  At the end of the 40 days, an automated process will remove the patient from the practice list if they have not already registered at an alternative GP.  I am glad that NHS111 were able to help you and hope that you have managed to source new services.

Thank you  for your feedback. We are sorry you have found it difficult to secure an appointment to discuss your result.   The demand for appointments is particularly high at the current time which has a knock on effect when booking routine appointments. We offer GP, smear and blood test appointments online.

signature: West Malling Group Practice
body:
We are sorry you have experienced problems trying to contact us by phone.  We endeavour to answer calls as quickly as possible to keep call wait times to acceptable levels however this has been challenging as some calls are complex.  We deploy staff from other teams within the Practice to answer calls at peak times in an attempt to reduce call wait times.  In addition, we have recruited new receptionists to the team who will be answering calls as soon as they have received training. 
Patients are also able to contact us via our contact submission available on our website westmallinggp.nhs.uk

signature: Salisbury Medical Practice
body:
We are sorry to learn that you have had a poor experience with the practice.  We have struggled with appointment availability which is why the trained call handlers will ask (from a script devised by the GPs) whether your request is new and urgent / requires same day treatment or ongoing and requires a routine appointment. I am delighted that we have 3 new GPs which have increased our appointment availability.  We have also opened up online booking through url link (successfully being used for adult and child flu clinics and we hope to expand this).  Unfortunately we have not yet extended this to GP appointment booking as we have been in short supply and wanted to ensure fairness by ensuring all patients use the same platform for requesting appointments.

We wish you all the best at your new practice.

Kind regards,
Salisbury Medical Practice

signature: Hawthorn Medical Practice
body:
Medical reports are not part of the practice's NHS contract and are treated as private work. This means that it is a separate workstream and the reports have to be completed by the doctors outside of their NHS work. For this reason we always advise that work may take up to six weeks to complete.
In order to help ensure that private work doesn't impact on our NHS work, the recorded message on our telephone system details the email address for the Admin staff member who deals with requests for non NHS work.

signature: The Southall Medical Ctr.
body:
Dear Patient,

Thank you for taking the time to leave this feedback of our GP surgery. Patient reviews are vital to help us continue to improve our services.

I am sorry to hear of your experience. I understand that you have struggled to book an appointment with the doctor. The easiest way is to complete the e-Consult form on our practice website. Once your form is submitted, it is triaged by our team by the end of the day and you will be advised a clinician will get in touch with you.

We understand that online services may not be easy for all our patients to use, or may not have access to them. In such situations, our reception team can guide you to complete the form or submit one on your behalf.

I am sorry you found the reception staff to be rude. I would like to reassure you that we have regular practice meetings and our staff have regular customer service and communications refresher training.

I will be sure to share your review with the practice team to help ensure these situations do not occur again.

Unfortunately, you have remained anonymous, and I am unable to look into your individual case further. However, if you would like to discuss your comments with the practice manager, please get in touch with this and we will be more than happy to do so.

Best wishes,
SMC management team

body:
We are very sorry to hear of your experience. As you have posted anonymously we cannot look into your specific details.
To clarify a few things, we run a triage system to enable the most appropriate method and time of appointment depending on the nature of the condition. We have a multidisciplinary team consisting of GPs, nurses, physician associates and pharmacists. We are also a training practice.
Face to face appointments are offered every day for those who the GP feels needs them. You can always request a clinician of your choice and if they are available they will contact you or arrange an appropriate appointment for you.
We have a stable reception team and have done for some time. 
We wish you well at your new practice.

body:
Hi Isabel,  
I had not forgotten about your response and offer to discuss my case.  
I have just returned from having to access private surgery outside of Scotland (having been donated funds to achieve this as I cannot afford it) having been left with no option. It is a terrible thing that the NHS doctors I tried to access repeatedly neglected me. It turned out I had severe deep infiltrating endometriosis not only on my reproductive organs but also on my bladder which was also adhered entirely to my uterus. I also had diffuse adenomyosis.  
All the disease has been removed and I am recovering well with no pelvic pain at all. It also looks like I have thoracic endometriosis, so given all of these findings I am even more devastated at how badly I was treated by the people that should have helped me.  
I will get in touch with you when I am further down the line of recovery. We can discuss whether it is appropriate for me to discuss this further with you or whether my hospital wide complaint to the QEUH about the gynaecology and surgical departments and staff means I cannot discuss at this point.

body:
**Posted on behalf of Geraldine Sparkes, Interim Lead Nurse, AMU / MAU**  
Dear fish and whistle  
Thank you for your feedback on Care Opinion, I'm sorry your experience in relation to MAU visiting was not a positive one with your relative, I apologise on behalf of the staff involved.  
I have since spoken to all the staff within MAU in relation to current protocol within NHS GGC. I circulated an update from the Core Brief, in regard to visiting on our site several weeks ago within our own teams and was disappointed to hear that this was not offered on this occasion. Please be advised I have re circulated this as well as highlighting this on daily safety briefs within the unit for staff awareness.  
Please be advised a maximum of two visitors can attend visiting at any one time to support relative/patient and be part of their ongoing care. This is in line with delivering patient centred care and implementing the NHS Core Values at all times. We also have local policies in relation to additional support required for any carer in line with The Carers Scotland Act 2016. Further information can be accessed at www.nhsggc.scot.carers  
If I can be of any further assistance, please don't hesitate to contact me directly  
Geraldine Sparkes  
Interim Lead Nurse  
AMU/MAU

ECMS

body:
As expected, another copy-paste response that proves the disinterest of the system - PALS and all. I've seen this exact message sent to almost every other serious complaint on here. At least change your adjectives or word-count to make it appear somewhat genuine.  
Also, why is the onus on me to chase you and demand a response when the issue is with 2 of the services you run? This is your problem to solve. I know it's probably asking too much but be proactive? If you are truly interested, you would at least attempt to contact the complainants yourselves yet here we are.  
I have been through the complaints system before and it has always been more trouble than it's worth. I recently complained about CAP (as per my above comment) which went nowhere. Someone called to speak to me, apologised, and agreed to send me a letter to document our conversation. The wrong letter was sent and the right one conveniently never appeared. I tried to contact the caller back and have received no calls in probably over a month. I don't expect anything from CAP now, even if my life were at risk. I have no doubt they have 'misplaced' my contact info or the contents of our discussion. This is the outcome of every complaint you - PALS and LPT - ever receive: nothing.  
I'm too unwell to deal with holding your hands. Sort it out yourselves. Maybe you can actually help someone else.

Good morning  
Thankyou for taking the time to reflect upon your attendance.  
We apologise you had to wait so long. Unfortunately on the day you arrived the hospital had 25 patients delayed in the ED waiting on admission beds. When we have a large number of delayed admissions we run out of clinical space and staff are stretched caring for these patients and new arrivals. The waiting time estimate should be explained at triage. We have a screen in one of the waiting areas which is waiting repair at present. This displays the waiting time. I have asked the ward sister to enquire have the maintenance department a timeframe for its repair.  
We have new chairs ordered for the waiting room but they have to be robust and be able to be sanitised with bleach.  
We appreciate your feedback.  
Regards  
Paul Smyth

You can do this via email to wxpals.bartshealth@nhs.net or telephone 0208 535 6438
Kind regards
Central Complaints Team
Barts Health NHS Trust

body: Thank you for taking the time to comment, we are glad you had a good experience at the flu clinic. The Hadleigh Practice

signature: Newbury Group Practice
body: Our original terxt invite indicated that the service would be operating from Fullwell Cross as a Covid vaccine was also on offer.  We became aware that on booking patients were sent an automated message saying the appointment was booked at Newbury Park.  We therefore sent an SMS message on Friday afternoon reminding everyone that the appointment would indeed be at Fullwell Cross.  For anyone contacted by telephone all were informed that the service would be operating from Fullwell Cross Health Centre.  We are sorry if you did not receive this information.
